Authors: Kusumajati D.A., Chairiyani R.P., Martoredjo N.T.
Title: The Influence of Social Media on Human Behavior in Adolescents (Case Study of Bina Nusantara University Students)
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Information System Department, School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center, Primary Teacher Education Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Character Building Development Center, Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kusumajati, D.A., Character Building Development Center, Information System Department, School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Chairiyani, R.P., Character Building Development Center, Primary Teacher Education Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Martoredjo, N.T., Character Building Development Center, Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The use of social media at this time cannot be separated from the needs of the community, in this case, they are teenagers. The use of social networks by students generates positive and negative behavioral changes. This study measures the effect of social networks on the behavior of human values in adolescents. The research subjects were active students studying at Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta. The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of social media on human behavior in adolescents.This research uses non-experimental quantitative methods. Data obtained from social media and human behavior measurement tools and have been tested on 473 students. The population in this study were active students at Bina Nusantara University. The results showed that there was an influence between social media and human behavior in social aspects and diversity. This means that the higher the use of social media by students increases the influence in social activities together with other people from various aspects of the background. © 2020 ACM.
Index Keywords: Behavioral research; Big data; Social aspects; Social networking (online); Students; Behavioral changes; Human behaviors; Human values; Quantitative method; Research subjects; Social activities; Social media; University students; Economic and social effects

Authors: Benawa A., Martoredjo N.T., Laurentius L.Y.
Title: The effect of lecturer leadership and organizational culture on the students' SPIRIT character building
Source title: Proceedings - 2017 10th International Conference on Human System Interactions, HSI 2017
Affiliations: CBDC, Marketing Communication Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; CBDC, Technical Information Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Benawa, A., CBDC, Marketing Communication Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Martoredjo, N.T., CBDC, Technical Information Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Laurentius, L.Y., CBDC, Technical Information Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The long-term goal of this research is to accommodate the students' perceptions of the influence of the lecturer's leadership and the organizational culture to the students' SPIRIT character development. The method that be used in this research is by distributing questionnaires to the respondents and the data obtained were processed quantitatively with path analysis. The results showed that the leadership of the lecturer did not have significant influence, because it only accounted for 12.1%, while the effect of organizational culture on the students' SPIRIT character development is also not significant, which amounted to 6.4%. It can be concluded that the leadership and organizational culture have no significant effect on the students' SPIRIT character development. So, it is very necessary to develop leadership and organizational culture in order to give significant effect to the students' SPIRIT character building. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Culture organization; Leadership; SPIRIT character building
Index Keywords: Regression analysis; Surveys; Leadership; Long-term goals; Organizational cultures; Path analysis; Students

Title: Enhancing student’s time management skills in the pursuit of professional character: A research on students at double degree program
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Martoredjo, N.T., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Lakonawa, P., Character Building Development Center, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Character building is one of the most significant parts of the efforts to develop human resources quality in the view of the present and future global career competition. Among all characters that are integral to the professional attitude is the ability to manage time ideally which is known as time management skills. This skill is so much decisive for the promotion of one’s career that requires the students to build a good habit of effective time management. This research attempts to describe how the above average level students (with GPA above 2.8) of double degree program manage their time. By using the method of direct observation and interviews, the research found that their academic achievement is so much determined by their ability to manage time. Their good time management habit significantly constitutes their professional attitude which would define their career progress in the future. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
References: Covey, S.R., (1998) The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People, , Binarupa Aksara, Jakarta; de Janasz, S.C., (2009) Interpersonal Skills in Organizations, , McGraw Hill, Boston; Claessens, J.C.B., Van Eerde, W., Rutte, G.C., Roe, R., A Review of Time Management Literatur (2007) Personnel Review, 36, pp. 255-276; Macan, T.H., Shahani, C., Dipboye, R.L., Phillips, A.P., (1990) Journal of Educational Psychology, 82, p. 760; Yager, J., (2004) Creative Time Management, , Bhuana Ilmu Populer, Jakarta; Hamzah, A.R., Lucky, E.O., Joarder, M.H., Time Management, External Motivation, and Students’ Academic Performance: Evidence from a Malaysian Public University (2014) Asian Social Science, 10, pp. 55-63; Kirillov, A.V., Tanatova, D.K., Vinichenko, M.V., Makushkin, S.A., Theory and Practice of Time-Management in Education (2015) Asian Social Science, 11, pp. 193-204; Yukselturk, E., Bulut, S., Predictors for Student Success in an Online Course (2007) Educational Technology and Society, 10, pp. 71-83; Lay, H.C., Schouwenburg, H., (1993) Journal of Social Behavior and Personality, 8, p. 647
